content.description: Identify pitch patterns that are played. In each case, the question number will be announced. You will have ten seconds to read the choices, and then you will hear the musical example played twice, with a brief pause between playings. Remember to read the choices for each question after its number is announced.
content.question: Which of the following is played?

choices.label: Score A has one staff in the treble clef, no key signature or time signature and only a single measure. The rhythm in score A is a set of seven quarter notes played in succession. The pitches in score A are: E4, D4, E4, F sharp 4, G4, A4, and B4.

Score B has one staff in the treble clef, no key signature or time signature and only a single measure. The rhythm in score B is a set of seven quarter notes played in succession. The pitches in score B are: E4, D4, E4, F sharp 4, G sharp 4, A4, and B4.

Score C has one staff in the treble clef, no key signature or time signature and only a single measure. The rhythm in score C is a set of seven quarter notes played in succession. The pitches in score C are: E4, D sharp 4, E4, F sharp 4, G4, A4, and B4.

Score D has one staff in the treble clef, no key signature or time signature and only a single measure. The rhythm in score D is a set of seven quarter notes played in succession. The pitches in score D are: E4, D sharp 4, E4, F sharp 4, G sharp 4, A4, and B4.

content.answer: Score D has one staff in the treble clef, no key signature or time signature and only a single measure. The rhythm in score D is a set of seven quarter notes played in succession. The pitches in score D are: E4, D sharp 4, E4, F sharp 4, G sharp 4, A4, and B4.

unit.text: 1: Music Fundamentals I - Pitch, Major Scales and Key Signatures, Rhythm, Meter, and Expressive Elements

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Use symbols and terms to describe features of pitch in performed music, including pitch patterns and relationships, melodic features, chords, harmonic progressions, and cadences.
